p: Another important chemical constituent in A. africana with significant anti-inflammatory potential is phytol, a diterpene alcohol [ 2, 20]). Phytol significantly inhibited paw edema development in mice ( p < 0.05) induced by carrageenan dose dependently [ 20]. When 75 mg/kg of phytol was administered to the mice, 51.8% inhibition of paw edema development was recorded after four hours [ 20]. Further, phytol caused a significant reduction ( p < 0.05) in the leukocyte recruitment and neutrophil migration to peritoneal cavity in mice [ 20]. Silva et al. [ 20] also observed that phytol significantly reduced interleukin-1 β and TNF- α levels ( p < 0.05) comparable to inhibitory effects produced by indomethacin. Thus, the anti-inflammatory effect exhibited by phytol is partly because it inhibits proinflammatory mediators and reduces migration of neutrophil and oxidative stress [ 20].
